commit_message:
Relocated "Neutron deployment use cases" section to improve flow

I think placing the "Neutron deployment use cases" section before the
"Installing Networking services" section may drive people to learn
more about typical Networking architectures before proceeding with
installation.

Change-Id: I0d7d9cb955a687d230f2e5621420534af7084cd4
Closes-Bug: #1263716

commit_message:
Refactor CIDR field to use netaddr.IPNetwork

This makes the CIDR field become the IPNetwork field (and associate
versioned fields). It also uses the netaddr.IPNetwork class, which
is what should have been done in the first place.

Wire format is unchanged, so we can make this without any version
bumps or upgrade impact.

Related to blueprint nova-network-objects

Change-Id: I1a3ab6a5f4c624f3da0ab1c78c75c6f1e474541f

commit_message:
Cleanup use of SEED_IP.

We don't advertise anything other than routing on SEED_IP - API
services are configured onto 192.0.2.1. Remove it from being saved or
referenced outside of devtest_seed.sh.

Change-Id: I430a7213da319b17aae12d34374a7967c43d2cbd

subject: Add a modifiable keyword for API validation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-15 09:19:35.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/test_api_validation.py', 'nova/api/validation/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d98d3b69960f7527007e34d7448f2ba009666926', 'message': "Add a modifiable keyword for API validation

Current validation framework checks a request body with keyword 'body'
because the wsgi framework passes it with the keyword.
However some core APIs(create a server API, etc.) passes it with the
other argument(server_dict, etc) to its extension methods.

For validating a request body at each extension method, this patch
adds a modifiable keyword.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: I56d5eab8f6d99934501357af3d7c6a5a0535fbe7
"}]
commit_message:
Add a modifiable keyword for API validation

Current validation framework checks a request body with keyword 'body'
because the wsgi framework passes it with the keyword.
However some core APIs(create a server API, etc.) passes it with the
other argument(server_dict, etc) to its extension methods.

For validating a request body at each extension method, this patch
adds a modifiable keyword.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-validation-fw

Change-Id: I56d5eab8f6d99934501357af3d7c6a5a0535fbe7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/82/66782/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def schema(request_body_schema, key='body'): :argument str key: a key to validate request body schema_validator.validate(kwargs[key])

commit_message:
Remove check for correct core_plugin when using ml2.

This checks fails, because $::neutron::core_plugin
is not available in the context of ml2.pp.

Change-Id: I96c11c5a57c530f72e0e71447831b8219c12a685

commit_message:
Add Python3 deprecated assert* to HACKING.rst

When we added H234 and H235 to check for deprecated asserts in Python
3.x (assert(Not)Equals, assert_), we forgot to add them to HACKING.rst

Change-Id: Id91977d76935998f5e5ae19dc089ee46d013aacb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/36/62136/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - ``assertEquals()`` is deprecated in in Python 3.x, use ``assertEqual()`` instead. The same goes for ``assertNotEquals()``. - ``assert_()`` is deprecated in Python 3.x, use ``assertTrue()`` instead.

commit_message:
Re-Add section on assertRaises(Exception

When hacking was originally part of nova, there was a section on
assertRaises but this was moved out of HACKING, and into
nova/tests/README.rst in nova change
I0e660b6c2a77c5613c5a523ba0a64c3d7f6dd128

Since hacking has been enforcing this rule, H202, from the beginning,
add this section back into HACKING.rst

Change-Id: Ia7e0c3f908136c75333cb66ff90c7990c80027be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/34/62134/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Unit Tests and assertRaises --------------------------- A properly written test asserts that particular behavior occurs. This can be a success condition or a failure condition, including an exception. When asserting that a particular exception is raised, the most specific exception possible should be used. In particular, testing for ``Exception`` being raised is almost always a mistake since it will match (almost) every exception, even those unrelated to the exception intended to be tested. This applies to catching exceptions manually with a try/except block, or using ``assertRaises()``. Example:: self.assertRaises(exception.InstanceNotFound, db.instance_get_by_uuid, elevated, instance_uuid)

commit_message:
Cleanup HACKING.rst

* remove two rules covered by pep8 since we already say 'see pep8' and
  gate on them via the pep8 tool:
* use code notation where appropriate
* fix formatting around apache2 header rule
* update import exceptions block, to match DEFAULT_IMPORT_EXCEPTIONS

Change-Id: I3febff29694865948c309340a20820c020e43d15

commit_message:
Move hacking guide to root directory

The hacking guide is in the root directory of every project as
HACKING.rst, except for hacking itself.  Keep the hacking guide as the
index to the docs, but move the file to the root directory.

Change-Id: If128dfc004db2b7427f987ea8a9f643b6c653ce8

commit_message:
Add 'api_workers' option to support multiple api services

Use the WSGI code from service.py to create multiple workers
processes to handle API load. Add 'api_workers' option to
config the number of api workers to start.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint multi-workers-for-api-server

Change-Id: I2f2033af7cb01c8c87f7f06d5c562065753550ed

commit_message:
Implements official clients with retry

Add function to monkey patched official clients to handle
retries on rate limiting errors.
Each client has an http client within, with something like
a request method. The request method is replaced with a new
request_with_retry, function of the original method.
For Swift using the existing retry functionality.

Also fixes self.config -> CONF

Closes-bug: #1250809
Closes-bug: #1187737

Change-Id: Iafad6b4047b860b88dce5743dcb83a438107958c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/78/61978/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinderclient import exceptions as cinderexcfrom glanceclient.common import exceptions as glanceexcfrom heatclient import exc as heatexcfrom keystoneclient import exceptions as keystoneexcfrom testtools import monkey import timeMAX_RECURSION_DEPTH = 2 RETRY_DELAY = 60 # secondsdef monkey_patch_manager_for_retry(manager_instance): # Mapping client / object / method mokey_patch_map = {'compute': {'client': 'client', 'method': 'request'}, 'image': {'client': None, 'method': '_http_request'}, 'network': {'client': 'httpclient', 'method': '_cs_request'}, 'volume': {'client': 'client', 'method': 'request'}, 'identity': {'client': None, 'method': 'request'}, 'orchestration': {'client': None, 'method': '_http_request'}} # Function to generate a patched function def get_request_with_retry(request_method): def request_with_retry(self, *args, **kwargs): saved_exc = None retries = 0 while retries < MAX_RECURSION_DEPTH: try: return request_method(self, *args, **kwargs) except (cinderexc.OverLimit, cinderexc.ClientException, nova_exceptions.OverLimit, nova_exceptions.ClientException, glanceexc.OverLimit, glanceexc.ClientException, keystoneexc.ClientException, heatexc.HTTPException) as ove: saved_exc = ove if hasattr(ove, 'message'): message = ove.message if not is_rate_limiting(ove.code, message): raise except exc.NeutronClientException as nce: saved_exc = nce if hasattr(nce, 'message'): message = nce.message if not is_rate_limiting(nce.status_code, message): raise else: # No exception, just continue to normal flow break # We only get here is we hit rate limiting LOG.debug('Request hit rate limiting. Try #{retry}'.format(retry=str(retries))) retries += 1 if retries < MAX_RECURSION_DEPTH: time.sleep(RETRY_DELAY) else: raise Exception("Exceeded MAX retries", saved_exc) return request_with_retry # Only patch OfficialClientManager if not isinstance(manager_instance, manager.OfficialClientManager): return manager_instance # Create the patcher patcher = monkey.MonkeyPatcher() # Build the patch list for service in mokey_patch_map.keys(): # Get the HTTP client try: client = getattr(manager_instance, ''.join([service, '_client'])) http_client_name = mokey_patch_map[service]['client'] if http_client_name is not None: client = getattr(client, http_client_name) # Get the request method request_method_name = mokey_patch_map[service]['method'] # Patch with the new method built on the original one patcher.add_patch(obj=client, name=request_method_name, value=get_request_with_retry(getattr(client, request_method_name))) except AttributeError: # Something's wrong with the object to be patched LOG.warn('Could not patch client for {service}'.format(service=service)) patcher.patch() return patcher.restore def is_rate_limiting(code, message): return (code == 429) or (code == 413 and 'rate-limited' in message) self.restore_me = monkey_patch_manager_for_retry(self)

commit_message:
Grant group member to has write access on the secret key store path

The httpd subprocess is running by apache user who is under apache
group, we need save the secret key store file into a path which apache
user has write access.

Close-bug: #1267691

Change-Id: Ia7effc95d62404c2b2901273909d69871c2d6899

commit_message:
move datastore manager to the datastore version

This moves the datastore manager field to the datastore version object
so that we can have managers per datastore version and they can be
shared if nessesary.

implements blueprint move-manager-to-datastore-version

Change-Id: I1c889a01005ec482bcd44e0e19475bc972e1af04

commit_message:
datastore manager moved to datastore version

Moving the manager from the datastore object to the datastore version
object to allow managers to be changed per version and this change is
reflected in the calls made to trove-manage to update the datastore and
datastore version.

paritally implements bp move-manager-to-datastore-version

Change-Id: I3c720153cbb08a8a3278debc3936854209576241

commit_message:
remove references and uses of fixed_range wrt nova.conf

Fixes: bug #1269876

As per commit https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/1f6c4f5,
fixed_range in nova.conf is deprecated.  We don't need to be setting it
any more.

Change-Id: Ie9371a54c3bcbad3c45b851b67f78c38c43940bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-compute refs/changes/37/67237/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * `openstack["compute"]["network"]["public_interface"]` - Defaults to eth0. Refers to the network interface used for VM addresses`.
deleted_lines: * `openstack["compute"]["network"]["fixed_range"]` - The CIDR for the network that VMs will be assigned to. In the case of VLAN Networking, this should be the network in which all VLAN networks that tenants are assigned will fit.* `openstack["compute"]["network"]["public_interface"]` - Defaults to eth0. Refers to the network interface used for VM addresses in the `fixed_range`.

commit_message:
Bugfix ring_script.rb output parser

This bugfix allows ring_script.rb to handler later versions
of swift-ring-builder that could be required in upgrade or
downgrade scenerios in the stable/grizzly branch.

Change-Id: I1fffddcf290fd077220021dd54df7f29ddfd7a8a
Partial-Bug: #1266922

commit_message:
Add possibility to create Failure from exception

In some cases it's great to have possibility to create
misc.Failure object from an exception directly. This
commit adds the 'from_exception' class method to create
misc.Failure in such way.

Change-Id: I44ae6720196b7bbe1e4ad538018487f0761a1af5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/62/67162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def from_exception(cls, exception): return cls((type(exception), exception, None))

commit_message:
Implement multi_part_mime hot intrinisic function

This would be useful to represent any kind of cloud-init
configuration in OS::Nova::Server user_data for
user_data_format=RAW

partial blueprint cloud-init-resource

Change-Id: I018900706ad126bcc7c7c7fed8bb9cf9ad576e63
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/94/59594/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import email def test_multi_part_mime(self): snippet = {'multi_part_mime': [ {'part': 'part1', 'filename': 'part1'}, {'part': 'part2', 'subtype': 'cloud-config'}, {'part': 'part3', 'filename': 'foo.txt'}, {'part': 'part4', 'filename': 'boothook.sh', 'subtype': 'cloud-boothook'}, {'filename': 'empty'} ]} tmpl = parser.Template(hot_tpl_empty) result = tmpl.resolve_multi_part_mime(snippet) msg = email.message_from_string(result) self.assertEqual('part1', msg.get_payload(0).get_payload()) self.assertEqual('part2', msg.get_payload(1).get_payload()) self.assertEqual('part3', msg.get_payload(2).get_payload()) self.assertEqual('part4', msg.get_payload(3).get_payload()) self.assertEqual('', msg.get_payload(4).get_payload()) self.assertEqual('text/part1', msg.get_payload(0).get_content_type()) self.assertEqual('text/cloud-config', msg.get_payload(1).get_content_type()) self.assertEqual('text/foo', msg.get_payload(2).get_content_type()) self.assertEqual('text/cloud-boothook', msg.get_payload(3).get_content_type()) self.assertEqual('text/empty', msg.get_payload(4).get_content_type()) self.assertEqual('part1', msg.get_payload(0).get_filename()) self.assertIsNone(msg.get_payload(1).get_filename()) self.assertEqual('foo.txt', msg.get_payload(2).get_filename()) self.assertEqual('boothook.sh', msg.get_payload(3).get_filename()) self.assertEqual('empty', msg.get_payload(4).get_filename()) def test_multi_part_mime_errors(self): tmpl = parser.Template(hot_tpl_empty) snippet = {'multi_part_mime': {}} self.assertRaises(TypeError, tmpl.resolve_multi_part_mime, snippet) snippet = {'multi_part_mime': [ ['part', 'part1', 'filename', 'part1'], ]} self.assertRaises(TypeError, tmpl.resolve_multi_part_mime, snippet) snippet = {'multi_part_mime': [ {'part': 'part1'} ]} self.assertRaises(KeyError, tmpl.resolve_multi_part_mime, snippet)

commit_message:
Move to use "get_password" instead of "{user,service,db}_password"

The user_password, service_password and db_password functions are redundant
since they simply call "secret". Creates a get_password function that will
accept a "type" of db, service or user.

All instances of these calls have been changed to call get_password

Change-Id: Ic73c99034638ec092192d11e37671edbba0e48ef
Partial-Bug: #1195915

commit_message:
Move to use "get_password" instead of "{user,service,db}_password"

The user_password, service_password and db_password functions are redundant
since they simply call "secret". Creates a get_password function thata will
accept a "type" of db, service or user.

All instances of these calls have been changed to call get_password

Change-Id: Ia4dbfe4ff794efc84c900950a666085deebaf7f3
Partial-Bug: #1195915

commit_message:
change default cinder.volume.driver

Fixes: bug #1269438

New lvm iscsi driver path is:

cinder.volume.drivers.lvm.LVMISCSIDriver

Change-Id: I3427e80c78ec52a6b02cd42d25f425e03e15f01f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-block-storage refs/changes/50/66850/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it "has correct volume.driver set" do expect(@chef_run).to render_file(@file.name).with_content("volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.lvm.LVMISCSIDriver") end

commit_message:
Refactoring local and scalable engines

* Moved iethods start_workflow_execution and convey_task_result into
 abstract engine
* Refactored existing local engine unit tests
* Added simple unit tests for scalable engine
* Minor cosmetic changes (imports, blank lines)

Change-Id: Ic781b134068f52ed5827b945fb57b202239fe9c4

commit_message:
Set default for USE_CACHE

This is usually set by devtest.sh but may not always be present, e.g. if
devtest_ramdisk.sh is called from toci or standalone.

Change-Id: Ib8ff6dcb6f467c7dc1e96973f814ed791741edd4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/38/67238/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: USE_CACHE=${USE_CACHE:-0}

'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2014-01-13 03:29:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/b6deb082b4319ee5192499e03721aaa77918f3a6', 'message': "Update toci_gate_test.sh to use the broker.

toci_gate_test now enters the broker and chains into toci_devtest.sh
via test-envclient. Under the hood this is doing:

$ testenv-client -b <geardserver>:4730 -- ./toci_devtest.sh

This depends on both a gearman broker and at least one registered
test env being deployed.

toci_devtest includes the code to apply the broker supplied SSH key to
the system and then attempts to run the first few stages of devtest,
preserving the test environment definintion from the broker.

The astute of eye may observe that we haven't solved how to pass the gear
server host into the test environment yet... that may require an
openstack-infra/config patch.

Change-Id: I53ce4ca687283a924ea055267ea90f20d6632651
Co-Authored-By: Robert Collins <rbtcollins@hp.com>
"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2014-01-15 08:14:56.000000000', 'files': ['toci_devtest.sh', 'toci_gate_test.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci/commit/81aa050b82d1d87e33976ae3c8645ca4c93216d0', 'message': "Update toci_gate_test.sh to use the broker.

toci_gate_test now enters the broker and chains into toci_devtest.sh
via test-envclient. Under the hood this is doing:

$ testenv-client -b <geardserver>:4730 -- ./toci_devtest.sh

This depends on both a gearman broker and at least one registered
test env being deployed.

toci_devtest includes the code to apply the broker supplied SSH key to
the system and then attempts to run the first few stages of devtest,
preserving the test environment definintion from the broker.

The astute of eye may observe that we haven't solved how to pass the gear
server host into the test environment yet... that may require an
openstack-infra/config patch.

commit_message:
Update toci_gate_test.sh to use the broker.

toci_gate_test now enters the broker and chains into toci_devtest.sh
via test-envclient. Under the hood this is doing:

$ testenv-client -b <geardserver>:4730 -- ./toci_devtest.sh

This depends on both a gearman broker and at least one registered
test env being deployed.

toci_devtest includes the code to apply the broker supplied SSH key to
the system and then attempts to run the first few stages of devtest,
preserving the test environment definintion from the broker.

The astute of eye may observe that we haven't solved how to pass the gear
server host into the test environment yet... that may require an
openstack-infra/config patch.

Change-Id: I53ce4ca687283a924ea055267ea90f20d6632651
Co-Authored-By: Robert Collins <rbtcollins@hp.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/29/61829/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -e . toci_functions.sh if [ ! -e "$TE_DATAFILE" ] ; then echo "Couldn't find data file" exit 1 fi function get_value(){ python -c "import simplejson; print simplejson.loads(open('$TE_DATAFILE').read()).get('$1','$2')" } SEED_IP=$(get_value seed-ip) HOST_IP=$(get_value host-ip) MACS=$(get_value node-macs) SSH_KEY=$(get_value ssh-key) echo $SSH_KEY >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys ssh_noprompt root@$HOST_IP echo "Im on the test env while its locked"

commit_message:
Only add ceilometer user to nova group if using compute agent

When using ceilometer outside of the compute context (ex: with the
swift middleware), puppet-ceilometer attempts to add the user to
the nova group which does not (and probably should not) exist on
the swift nodes.

Change-Id: I6cc68152325a967c024ce611f92a90ce0afba8cc
(cherry picked from commit d064997cd4c50d9b5365fe2ffca60e14a86b08e1)

commit_message:
Fix pep error "E121"/"E126"

Currently, "run_tests.sh -p " reported E126, E121, E122 and E128 as
pep error.

This patch fixes E121 and E126.

Change-Id: Ifcb34454cabc44e04297f1aa7383aa116066cf73

commit_message:
Add Tripleo CI user.

This will permit Tripleo CI to obtain IPs from neutron in
ci-overcloud.tripleo.org(the ci overcloud). Once merged the user will
need to be added manually to the ci-overcloud, this should eventually be
automated and persisted when we move to the cd-overcloud.

Change-Id: I9c312fdc71895544ed34bfe4c3abf6aa5a2ea4ef

commit_message:
Add a db check for CHARSET=utf8

This is to prevent confusing migration errors caused by
tables having mixed character sets like latin1.

Change-Id: I19da8d5e2d972c78d0f9fb4325445f538ed35600
Closes-bug: #1261605

commit_message:
Use entry points to discover options in libraries

When generating the sample configuration file, we want to include
options defined in libraries used by the application (especially
oslo libraries). Add a section to the sample generator to look
at entry points in the 'oslo.config.opts' namespace and include
their return values in the output.

Implements: blueprint improve-config-discovery-for-docs
Related-Bug: #1241566

Change-Id: I635cd8e60ca687851c9dd891667ecc2ca3e8720c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/55/66955/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import argparseimport stevedore.nameddef generate(argv): parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( description='generate sample configuration file', ) parser.add_argument('-l', dest='libraries', action='append') parser.add_argument('srcfiles', nargs='*') parsed_args = parser.parse_args(argv) for filepath in parsed_args.srcfiles: # Look for entry points defined in libraries (or applications) for # option discovery, and include their return values in the output. # # Each entry point should be a function returning an iterable # of pairs with the group name (or None for the default group) # and the list of Opt instances for that group. if parsed_args.libraries: loader = stevedore.named.NamedExtensionManager( 'oslo.config.opts', names=list(set(parsed_args.libraries)), invoke_on_load=False, ) for ext in loader: for group, opts in ext.plugin(): opt_list = opts_by_group.setdefault(group or 'DEFAULT', []) opt_list.append((ext.name, opts))
deleted_lines: def generate(srcfiles): for filepath in srcfiles:

commit_message:
Move to use "get_password" instead of "{user,service,db}_password"

The user_password, service_password and db_password functions are redundant
since they simply call "secret". Creates a get_password function that will
accept a "type" of db, service or user.

All instances of these calls have been changed to call get_password

Change-Id: Ifdb5c7b3f590431aaa7ffc021cdee34899ac8c15
Partial-Bug: #1195915

commit_message:
Move to use "get_password" instead of "{user,service,db}_password"

The user_password, service_password and db_password functions are redundant
since they simply call "secret". Creates a get_password function that will
accept a "type" of db, service or user.

All instances of these calls have been changed to call get_password

Change-Id: I5093b7b4055ef0140dfbe36f96466cf0b38efc68
Partial-Bug: #1195915
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-image refs/changes/05/66805/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: service_pass = secret node['openstack']['secret']['service_passwords_data_bag'], 'openstack-image'

commit_message:
Enable setting up translation handler via CONF

Just like with other log settings, enable setting up the
TranslationHandler via a CONF option, outside the logging.conf
file. The patch adds a new CONF option called 'log_additional_locale'.

Change-Id: I71e0a564e13b782d741a4e5eafe30bf82569a02c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/08/62508/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch('openstack.common.gettextutils.get_available_languages') def test_secondary_locale_log_option(self, mock_get_locales): mock_get_locales.return_value = ['en_US', 'es'] log_dir = tempfile.mkdtemp() additional_locale = 'es' self.CONF(['--log-dir', log_dir]) self.CONF.set_default('use_stderr', False) try: # Fist test a non-installed locale self.CONF.log_additional_locale = 'fr' log._setup_logging_from_conf() self.fail('Expected LogConfigError') except log.LogConfigError: pass self.CONF.log_additional_locale = additional_locale log._setup_logging_from_conf() logger = log._loggers[None].logger self.assertEqual(2, len(logger.handlers)) self.assertIsInstance(logger.handlers[0], logging.handlers.WatchedFileHandler) # If the log_additional_locale property is used, in addition to the # default log file handler, there will be a TranslationHandler and # a new directory for the additional log with the name of the locale self.assertIsInstance(logger.handlers[1], gettextutils.TranslationHandler) self.assertTrue(os.path.exists('%s/%s' % (log_dir, additional_locale)))

commit_message:
Disable verbose logging by default

cliff app will manage logging level instead of making it manually

Closes-Bug: #1269729
Change-Id: I8f75c1c086c7c7bca6531e7244785caaa69d4a88

added_lines: DEFAULT_VERBOSE_LEVEL = 0 def initialize_app(self, argv): super(DesignateShell, self).initialize_app(argv) # Set requests logging to a useful level requests_log = logging.getLogger('requests') if self.options.debug: requests_log.setLevel(logging.DEBUG) else: requests_log.setLevel(logging.WARNING)

commit_message:
Sync gettextutils from Oslo

The Message class in Oslo, in charge of providing delayed translation
features, was improved and a new feature was implemented to enable
creation of addition logs in different locales.

Latest Oslo commit:
221c37d Allow the Message class to have non-English default locales

bp i18n-messages

Change-Id: I9ac8a0da9ea3b7b393f81c255332d83bbcab1da9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/76/66976/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import locale from logging import handlers return Message(msg, domain='neutron') return Message(msg, domain=domain)class Message(six.text_type): """A Message object is a unicode object that can be translated. Translation of Message is done explicitly using the translate() method. For all non-translation intents and purposes, a Message is simply unicode, and can be treated as such. """ def __new__(cls, msgid, msgtext=None, params=None, domain='neutron', *args): """Create a new Message object. In order for translation to work gettext requires a message ID, this msgid will be used as the base unicode text. It is also possible for the msgid and the base unicode text to be different by passing the msgtext parameter. """ # If the base msgtext is not given, we use the default translation # of the msgid (which is in English) just in case the system locale is # not English, so that the base text will be in that locale by default. if not msgtext: msgtext = Message._translate_msgid(msgid, domain) # We want to initialize the parent unicode with the actual object that # would have been plain unicode if 'Message' was not enabled. msg = super(Message, cls).__new__(cls, msgtext) msg.msgid = msgid msg.domain = domain msg.params = params return msg def translate(self, desired_locale=None): """Translate this message to the desired locale. :param desired_locale: The desired locale to translate the message to, if no locale is provided the message will be translated to the system's default locale. :returns: the translated message in unicode """ translated_message = Message._translate_msgid(self.msgid, self.domain, desired_locale) if self.params is None: # No need for more translation return translated_message # This Message object may have been formatted with one or more # Message objects as substitution arguments, given either as a single # argument, part of a tuple, or as one or more values in a dictionary. # When translating this Message we need to translate those Messages too translated_params = _translate_args(self.params, desired_locale) translated_message = translated_message % translated_params return translated_message @staticmethod def _translate_msgid(msgid, domain, desired_locale=None): if not desired_locale: system_locale = locale.getdefaultlocale() # commit_message:
lockutils: remove local usage

This doesn't seem like it's used by anything any more, so let's just
remove this local usage altogether. This also drops the lock check from
RPC, which shouldn't be a problem considering that this library is
already deprecated altogether.

Change-Id: I87ff0338adcfa092fd21acad5cf41d5746be1efe

subject: test: Use srmock header_dict in preparation for Falcon 0.1.8
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-08 19:48:41.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/queues/transport/wsgi/test_queue_lifecycle.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zaqar/commit/4d8f1b6ea8e5ce0738f1d7e645d3a36f2bd7f9a0', 'message': 'test: Use srmock header_dict in preparation for Falcon 0.1.8

Falcon 0.1.8 returns lowercased headers to the client. This *should* be
OK, since well-behaved clients treat headers as case-insensitive. However,
srmock exposes the response headers directly and we do an assert using
them without taking into account case of the header name.

This patch modifies that particular assert to use srmock.header_dict
instead, since in 0.1.8 that is implemented using a case-insensitive
dict.

Change-Id: Ib7435a0a51ccf1d5d1ab8da672a12cf3233f9e8e
'}]
commit_message:
test: Use srmock header_dict in preparation for Falcon 0.1.8

Falcon 0.1.8 returns lowercased headers to the client. This *should* be
OK, since well-behaved clients treat headers as case-insensitive. However,
srmock exposes the response headers directly and we do an assert using
them without taking into account case of the header name.

This patch modifies that particular assert to use srmock.header_dict
instead, since in 0.1.8 that is implemented using a case-insensitive
dict.

Change-Id: Ib7435a0a51ccf1d5d1ab8da672a12cf3233f9e8e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/21/65521/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: location = self.srmock.headers_dict['Location'] self.assertEqual(location, '/v1/queues/gumshoe')

commit_message:
Ceilometer endpoint doesn't need last slash

The last slash is unnecessary, it only causes redundant slash when
generate api uri, which already treated as a bug in Ceilometer.

Change-Id: I758d76e8edab6e818989bac8e05eb17c6e373546
Closes-Bug: #1269496
backport: havana
ref: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/63279/

commit_message:
Policy management for Climate

Implements policies in Climate with unittests based on Oslo.
Tight integration with Context as it will populate to Context
if user is admin or not based on policy.json

In order to make that work, please add policy.json to /etc/climate

Decorator @policy.authorize allows enforcing policy checks on
controllers.

Implements bp:climate-policy

Change-Id: I94e8fa142e5c5d830b0bea9278e5a47f9904db4c

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2013 Bull. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. """Test of Policy Engine For Climate.""" import os.path import StringIO import urllib2 from climate import context from climate import exceptions from climate.openstack.common import log as logging from climate.openstack.common import policy as common_policy from climate import policy from climate.tests import policy_fixture from climate import test from climate import utils LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class PolicyFileTestCase(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(PolicyFileTestCase, self).setUp() self.context = context.Context('fake', 'fake') self.target = {} def test_modified_policy_reloads(self): with utils.tempdir() as tmpdir: tmpfilename = os.path.join(tmpdir, 'policy') self.flags(policy_file=tmpfilename) policy.reset() action = "example:test" with open(tmpfilename, "w") as policyfile: policyfile.write('{"example:test": ""}') ret = policy.enforce(self.context, action, self.target) self.assertEquals(True, ret) with open(tmpfilename, "w") as policyfile: policyfile.write('{"example:test": "!"}') self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, self.context, action, self.target) # class PolicyTestCase(test.TestCase): # def setUp(self): # super(PolicyTestCase, self).setUp() # rules = { # "true": '@', # "example:allowed": '@', # "example:denied": "!", # "example:get_http": "http://www.example.com", # "example:my_file": "role:compute_admin or " # "project_id:%(project_id)s", # "example:early_and_fail": "! and @", # "example:early_or_success": "@ or !", # "example:lowercase_admin": "role:admin or role:sysadmin", # "example:uppercase_admin": "role:ADMIN or role:sysadmin", # } # self.policy = self.useFixture(policy_fixture.PolicyFixture()) # self.policy.set_rules(rules) # self.context = context.Context('fake', 'fake', roles=['member']) # self.target = {} # def test_enforce_nonexistent_action_throws(self): # action = "example:noexist" # self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, # self.context, action, self.target) # def test_enforce_bad_action_throws(self): # action = "example:denied" # self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, # self.context, action, self.target) # def test_enforce_bad_action_noraise(self): # action = "example:denied" # result = policy.enforce(self.context, action, self.target, False) # self.assertEqual(result, False) # def test_enforce_good_action(self): # action = "example:allowed" # result = policy.enforce(self.context, action, self.target, False) # self.assertEqual(result, True) # def test_enforce_http_true(self): # def fakeurlopen(url, post_data): # return StringIO.StringIO("True") # self.stubs.Set(urllib2, 'urlopen', fakeurlopen) # action = "example:get_http" # target = {} # result = policy.enforce(self.context, action, target) # self.assertEqual(result, True) # def test_enforce_http_false(self): # def fakeurlopen(url, post_data): # return StringIO.StringIO("False") # self.stubs.Set(urllib2, 'urlopen', fakeurlopen) # action = "example:get_http" # target = {} # self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, # self.context, action, target) # def test_templatized_enforcement(self): # target_mine = {'project_id': 'fake'} # target_not_mine = {'project_id': 'another'} # action = "example:my_file" # policy.enforce(self.context, action, target_mine) # self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, # self.context, action, target_not_mine) # def test_early_AND_enforcement(self): # action = "example:early_and_fail" # self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, # self.context, action, self.target) # def test_early_OR_enforcement(self): # action = "example:early_or_success" # policy.enforce(self.context, action, self.target) # def test_ignore_case_role_check(self): # lowercase_action = "example:lowercase_admin" # uppercase_action = "example:uppercase_admin" # # NOTE(dprince) we mix case in the Admin role here to ensure # # case is ignored # admin_context = context.RequestContext('admin', # 'fake', # roles=['AdMiN']) # policy.enforce(admin_context, lowercase_action, self.target) # policy.enforce(admin_context, uppercase_action, self.target) class DefaultPolicyTestCase(test.TestCase): def fake_load_rules(self, force_reload=None): LOG.debug("Fake Load rules") policy.set_rules(self.rules) def setUp(self): super(DefaultPolicyTestCase, self).setUp() self.rules = """ { "default": '', "example:exist": "!", "example:allowed": '@' } """ self.policy = self.useFixture(policy_fixture.PolicyFixture()) self.patch(policy._ENFORCER, 'load_rules').\ side_effect = self.fake_load_rules # self._set_rules('default') self.target = {} self.context = context.Context('fake', 'fake', roles=['member']) # def _set_rules(self, default_rule): # self.policy.set_rules(self.rules, default_rule) def test_policy_called(self): self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, self.context, "example:exist", {}) def test_not_found_policy_calls_default(self): result = policy.enforce(self.context, "example:noexist", {}, False) self.assertEquals(result, False) def test_default_not_found(self): self._set_rules("default_noexist") self.assertRaises(exceptions.PolicyNotAuthorized, policy.enforce, self.context, "example:noexist", {}) def test_enforce_good_action(self): action = "example:allowed" result = policy.enforce(self.context, action, {}, False) self.assertEqual(result, True)

commit_message:
Deletion of powervm virt driver mention

Due a change in IBM strategy, powervm has been removed, and its mention
has to be deleted from icehouse documentation.

Change-Id: I9dd9fc4a5032ac6c9094142f20e944dbda40015d
Partial-Bug: #1255422

commit_message:
renamed OS-IDP spec file to OS-FEDERATION

This could have been done as part of a previous change [1] which
expanded the scope of the extension, but it made the diff in gerrit very
difficult to see additional changes. This is ONLY the file rename.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/59848/

Change-Id: Ibce5940b61926028774f9c02e533d67ca958662f

subject: Allow different login methods to be used with kombu connections.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-16 17:08:38.000000000', 'files': ['openstack/common/rpc/impl_kombu.py', 'tests/unit/rpc/test_kombu.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator/commit/637d673760ac98708d6d611497d0cde55abf8ecf', 'message': 'Allow different login methods to be used with kombu connections.

Currently it is not possible to modify the login method used with
kombu connections via configuration files, and requires modifying
the source code to actually add a login method in the first place.
This adds a configuration option (and default) which are passed to
the underlying kombu connection.

Change-Id: I6ff421a65b0e6f93db76d91e9362cd63d9170299

commit_message:
Allow different login methods to be used with kombu connections.

Currently it is not possible to modify the login method used with
kombu connections via configuration files, and requires modifying
the source code to actually add a login method in the first place.
This adds a configuration option (and default) which are passed to
the underlying kombu connection.

Unit tests have also been corrected to the best of my knowledge.

Closes-Bug: #1269867
Change-Id: I6ff421a65b0e6f93db76d91e9362cd63d9170299

commit_message:
Disallow new provision for nodes in maintenance

New deploy operation will not allowed for nodes in
'maintenance' mode.

Partial-Bug: #1260099
Change-Id: Idaf8c3d70bd78b2c95bbdcff734e235eb8063d91

commit_message:
Add pywbem to global-requirements.txt

The EMC volume driver in Cinder requires the pywbem package to
be available.  This is the first part of the changes required to
enable the package being automatically included by Cinder.

Change-Id: I7fa402f64e7170bb9ebd85bd67efe67e0d1d1736
Partial-Bug: 1204229

commit_message:
Add shard support to the client

The patch adds Shard support of the client. This will allow users to
create and delete shards from Marconi. The API requires the Marconi
instance to be and admin instance. However, there are no checks,
restrictions, yet.

This patch doesn't implement Shards listing. As soon as the
MessageIterator lands, it'll be possible to reuse that code for the
ShardsIterator.

Partially-Implements blueprint: shard-management
Partially-Implements blueprint: python-marconiclient-v1

Change-Id: I932c98d68a4a81b710dbea75a6bac123b7afaa08
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zaqarclient refs/changes/29/64829/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def shard_create(transport, request, shard_name, shard_data): """Creates a shard called `shard_name` :param transport: Transport instance to use :type transport: `transport.base.Transport` :param request: Request instance ready to be sent. :type request: `transport.request.Request` :param shard_name: Shard reference name. :type shard_name: `six.text_type` :param shard_data: Shard's properties, i.e: weight, uri, options. :type shard_data: `dict` """ request.operation = 'shard_create' request.params['shard_name'] = shard_name request.content = json.dumps(shard_data) transport.send(request) def shard_delete(transport, request, shard_name): """Deletes the shard `shard_name` :param transport: Transport instance to use :type transport: `transport.base.Transport` :param request: Request instance ready to be sent. :type request: `transport.request.Request` :param shard_name: Shard reference name. :type shard_name: `six.text_type` """ request.operation = 'shard_delete' request.params['shard_name'] = shard_name transport.send(request)

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: test out eatmydata

LD_PRELOAD library that disables all forms of writing data safely to
disk. fsync() becomes a NO-OP, O_SYNC is removed etc.

The idea is to use in testing to get faster test runs where real
durability is not required.

https://launchpad.net/libeatmydata

Change-Id: I97b425dc8ea97007a3ae1865e4d831ed10a47b57

commit_message:
Use the test env JSON to detect remote VM hosts.

This permits devtest_seed to automatically do the right thing in a
TripleO-CI environment. Well, nearly - we still need to fixup some of
the post boot steps, but we should at least have a seed booting from
this.

Change-Id: I1fedc9e41ba2eec96bd21ec618ff48a678a383ce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/49/66249/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo echo "If host-ip (and possibly ssh-user) is set in the JSON then those details" echo "are used to construct a remote libvirt URL and spawn the VM remotely." echo "Note that seed-ip *must* be present when doing this. When spawning remotely" echo "the image is copied to that host via rsync, and a remote virsh URI is used." echo "However SSH access with rsync write access to /var/lib/libvirt/images/," echo "permission to chattr, and the ability to run virsh as the selected user are" echo "requirements."HOST_IP=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$TE_DATAFILE os-apply-config --key host-ip --type netaddress --key-default '') if [ -n "$HOST_IP" ]; then SSH_USER=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$TE_DATAFILE os-apply-config --key ssh-user --type raw --key-default '') if [ -n "$SSH_USER" ]; then SSH_USER="${SSH_USER}@" fi VM_HOST=${SSH_USER}${HOST_IP} echo $VM_HOST fi
deleted_lines: VM_HOST="" echo " -r VM_HOST -- Use a VM on a remote host. This causes the image to" echo " be copied to that host via rsync, and a remote virsh" echo " URI to be used. VM_HOST can be an ssh [user@]host." echo " However SSH access with rsync write access to" echo " /var/lib/libvirt/images/, permission to chattr, and " echo " the ability to run virsh as the selected user are" echo " requirements" -r) export VM_HOST=$2; shift 2 ;;

commit_message:
Use the JSON description to probe the seed VM.

This adds a dependency on jq to let us cleanly write autodetected seed
VM IP addresses into the test file, which will simplify things later
on in our workflow. Using the datafile is preferrable to complex
checks in devtest which is afterall meant to be as much manual as
script.

Change-Id: I81e49d16077c564dd1e5d3e6f6e7a26e7c56ef5c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/48/66248/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -o pipefail echo "The environment variable TE_DATAFILE must be set, pointing at a test" echo "environment JSON file. If seed-ip is present in the JSON then that is" echo "used for the VM IP address, otherwise it is discovered by probing the" echo "ARP table and then saved back into the JSON file." echo exit $1 -h) show_options 0;;if [ -z "$TE_DATAFILE" ]; then echo "Error: TE_DATAFILE not set." show_options 1 fi VM_IP=$(OS_CONFIG_FILES=$TE_DATAFILE os-apply-config --key seed-ip --type raw --key-default '')NEW_JSON=$(jq '.["seed-ip"]="'${VM_IP}'"' $TE_DATAFILE) echo $NEW_JSON > $TE_DATAFILE
deleted_lines: echo " --ip IP -- set the IP address the seed will start on," echo " this is useful for remote VM's where MAC probing" echo " would fail" exit 0 -h) show_options;; --ip) export VM_IP=$2; shift 2 ;;export VM_IP

commit_message:
Update RPC code from oslo

The common RPC code has been updated to include the following:
    8575d87af49ea276341908f83c8c51db13afca44
    8b2b0b743e84ceed7841cf470afed6a5da8e1d07
    23f602940c64ba408d77ceb8f5ba0f67ee4a18ef
    6d0a6c3083218cdac52758a8b6aac6b03402c658
    7cac1ac1bd9df36d4e5183afac3b643df10b1d4d
    8159efddabb09dd9b7c99963ff7c9de0a6c62b62

Updated to include the following in modules in openstack-common.conf:
py3kcompat, sslutils, and versionutils.

The update also includes imports from the RPC code

Change-Id: I84c5b8e2b17da0018dd69ecb354d123a609afe98

added_lines: # this check when the master list updates to >=1.0, and update all projects """Gets a localized version of the given message in the given locale. If the message is not a Message object the message is returned as-is. If the locale is None the message is translated to the default locale. :returns: the translated message in unicode, or the original message if it could not be translated """ translated = message if isinstance(message, Message): original_locale = message.locale message.locale = user_locale translated = six.text_type(message) message.locale = original_locale return translated
deleted_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 # this check when the master list updates to >=1.0, and all projects udpate """Gets a localized version of the given message in the given locale.""" if isinstance(message, Message): if user_locale: message.locale = user_locale return six.text_type(message) else: return message

commit_message:
Make download an action rather than a column

Removed download column.
Created download action that uses containers object_download url.
Fixed spelling of datum in existing action.

Closes-Bug: #1250584
Closes-Bug: #1250599

Change-Id: Ia75080553f97f4eb2b5f4f4c3fc3e550fd318655
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/86/56086/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_link_url(self, datum): return url + '?backup=%s' % datum.id class DownloadBackup(tables.LinkAction): name = "download" verbose_name = _("Download Backup") url = 'horizon:project:containers:object_download' classes = ("btn-launch",) def get_link_url(self, datum): container_name, object_path = datum.locationRef.split('/')[-2:] return reverse(self.url, kwargs={'container_name': container_name, 'object_path': object_path}) def allowed(self, request, datum): return datum.status == 'COMPLETED' row_actions = (RestoreLink, DownloadBackup, DeleteBackup)
deleted_lines: def get_link_url(self, datam): return url + '?backup=%s' % datam.id location = tables.Column(lambda obj: _("Download"), link=lambda obj: obj.locationRef, verbose_name=_("Backup File")) row_actions = (RestoreLink, DeleteBackup)

commit_message:
Do not filter image list from glance api

Horizon filter glance image list because 'aki', 'ari' type of images
can not be launchable.

However, it is better to provide full capacity with glance in
Horizon.

Reasons:
1. Horizon allow upload those images. It brings confusion if not
show them
2. The filtering strange behavior when pagination is enabled

Changed to show all images in Horizon, but 'aki', 'ari' type of
images are not allowed to launch or create volume.

Change-Id: Ic92fc97d7327bb2525c0155646487dd685e99c79
Closes-Bug: #1257180

commit_message:
Fix updating device names when defaulting

If the virt driver does not support defaulting device names, the default
behaviour of defaulting them in the manager was calling the conductor
block_device_mapping_update method with the wrong arguments, which
caused a TypeError and ultimately a failure to boot the instance.

This patch fixed the signature and adds a test that exercises it so
that it does not regress.

Closes-bug: #1260806
Change-Id: I6116540c9aca4847afacf80b3d1e0c027c364159

Expose some SLO constraints via /info

These are the ones that affect what requests a client can make; the
others are just time and speed limits, so they weren't as interesting.

commit_message:
tests: pass /dev/null as config for mongod

On certain system, such as Darwin, the default mongod binary is a
wrapper adding a default configuration file. Let's specify that there's
no configuration file to read, otherwise a log file is used instead of
stdout.

Change-Id: I56c72cd61399405fd57d6e3f2b1f53ca6a395835
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/73/65473/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mongod --maxConns 32 --nojournal --noprealloc --smallfiles --quiet --noauth --port ${MONGO_PORT} --dbpath "${MONGO_DATA}" --bind_ip localhost --config /dev/null &>${MONGO_DATA}/out &

Provide message when server not deleted

Added exception raising when server was not deleted which
leads to test failure upon instance deletion step.
Added minor changes to tests.

Closes-bug: 1262128

subject: Add a swift-enabled version of WordCount to edp-examples
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-14 19:34:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara-extra/commit/353911813fa2ef781586de5e524be4f96351e721', 'message': 'Add a swift-enabled version of WordCount to edp-examples

The edp-wordcount example includes source code and instructions on
how to build the jar and run it from the Oozie command line or the

commit_message:
Add a swift-enabled version of WordCount to edp-examples

The edp-wordcount example includes source code and instructions on
how to build the jar and run it from the Oozie command line or the
Savanna UI. WordCount will work with hdfs paths, or with swift paths
as long as the proper configs are set.

Change-Id: I9ac728de505d874fd50a6baf75b062d5b622f3d0

commit_message:
Set default bus to SCSI for Power KVM

KVM default bus for x86 are set to ide and virtio for cdrom and
disk, respectively. Adding Power support with bus type SCSI.

Change-Id: I7da4262553f54b48722075534afc888ce87dd03b

commit_message:
Fix use the fact that empty sequences are false

For sequences(strings, lists, tuples), in order to consistent with
pep8 recommendations, 'if len(seq)' should be replaced with 'if seq',
and 'if not len(seq)' should be replaced with 'if not seq'.

Change-Id: Ie7b6afbde07bb57a05b36d92a079c5355945b262
Closes-Bug: #1265688

commit_message:
Remove heat-cli-guide

The heat command line clients are documented now better in the
OpenStack End User Guide:

http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/heat-stack-create.html
http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide/content/heat_client_commands.html

The content here is thus not needed anymore, as the README.rst says:
"This documentation should eventually end up in the OpenStack
documentation repositories `api-site` and `openstack-manuals`."

Change-Id: I297252d7f8eee383ce6252a5db44111630fbe29b

deleted_lines: Install OpenStack heat CLI This example walks through installing the heat client. After you install a client, you must configure environment variables for authentication. To install the heat client: Install Python Install Python 2.6 or later. Currently, the heat client does not support Python 3. Install the heat client package Choose one of the following methods to install the heat client package. Recommended method: pip Install pip through the package manager for your system: System Command Mac OS X $ sudo easy_install pip Ubuntu $ aptitude install python-pip RHEL, CentOS, or Fedora: $ yum install python-pip Run the following command to install the heat client package: $ sudo pip install python-heatclient easy_install Run the following command to install the heat client package: $ sudo easy_install python-heatclient Get help for heat client commands To get help for heat client commands, run the following command: $ heat -h Depending on your user credentials, you may not have permissions to use every command that is listed. The heat client was written for use with recent development versions of OpenStack. To get help for a specific command, type the command name after the help parameter, as follows: $ heat help <command_name>

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2012 OpenStack Foundation # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Base utilities to build API operation managers and objects on top of. """ import copy import six # Python 2.4 compat try: all except NameError: def all(iterable): return True not in (not x for x in iterable) def getid(obj): """Get by object or ID. Abstracts the common pattern of allowing both an object or an object's ID (UUID) as a parameter when dealing with relationships. """ try: return obj.id except AttributeError: return obj class Manager(object): """Managers interact with a particular type of API. For example servers, flavors and images. It provides CRUD operations for these objects. """ resource_class = None def __init__(self, api): self.api = api def _list(self, url, response_key, obj_class=None, body=None): resp, body = self.api.json_request('GET', url) if obj_class is None: obj_class = self.resource_class data = body[response_key] return [obj_class(self, res, loaded=True) for res in data if res] def _delete(self, url): self.api.raw_request('DELETE', url) def _update(self, url, body, response_key=None): resp, body = self.api.json_request('PUT', url, body=body) # PUT requests may not return a body if body: return self.resource_class(self, body[response_key]) class Resource(object): """A resource represents a particular instance of an object. For example tenant or user. This is pretty much just a bag for attributes. :param manager: Manager object :param info: dictionary representing resource attributes :param loaded: prevent lazy-loading if set to True """ def __init__(self, manager, info, loaded=False): self.manager = manager self._info = info self._add_details(info) self._loaded = loaded def _add_details(self, info): for (k, v) in six.iteritems(info): setattr(self, k, v) def __getattr__(self, k): if k not in self.__dict__: #NOTE(bcwaldon): disallow lazy-loading if already loaded once if not self.is_loaded(): self.get() return self.__getattr__(k) raise AttributeError(k) else: return self.__dict__[k] def __repr__(self): reprkeys = sorted(k for k in self.__dict__.keys() if k[0] != '_' and k != 'manager') info = ", ".join("%s=%s" % (k, getattr(self, k)) for k in reprkeys) return "<%s %s>" % (self.__class__.__name__, info) def get(self): # set_loaded() first ... so if we have to bail, we know we tried. self.set_loaded(True) if not hasattr(self.manager, 'get'): return new = self.manager.get(self.id) if new: self._add_details(new._info) def __eq__(self, other): if not isinstance(other, self.__class__): return False if hasattr(self, 'id') and hasattr(other, 'id'): return self.id == other.id return self._info == other._info def is_loaded(self): return self._loaded def set_loaded(self, val): self._loaded = val def to_dict(self): return copy.deepcopy(self._info)

subject: VMware: driver - assert open session before operations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-14 15:16:00.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/vmwareapi/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/2226b8a30dd3886e869883380fed25790ec3729e', 'message': 'VMware: driver - assert open session before operations

There will be multiple points in the driver where the code
has been state-ful presuming preserved "open session state"
this assumption will have to be baked out of the code a
line at a time.

In this example I'm leaning on the ability to create/join
an open session.

The use of self._session should be treated as "code smell" an
indication that something may be wrong (but not necessarily so).

Change-Id: I48da8faaeba83af3052ae6a35f8fca63dd580fd5
'}]
commit_message:
VMware: driver - assert open session before operations

There will be multiple points in the driver where the code
has been state-ful presuming preserved "open session state"
this assumption will have to be baked out of the code a
line at a time.

In this example I'm leaning on the ability to create/join
an open session.

The use of self._session should be treated as "code smell" an
indication that something may be wrong (but not necessarily so).

Change-Id: I48da8faaeba83af3052ae6a35f8fca63dd580fd5

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import imp import os from inspect import getmembers from inspect import isclass from nailgun.api.urls.v1 import urls from nailgun.autoapidoc import SampleGenerator from nailgun.test.base import BaseIntegrationTest class TestAPIDocGeneration(BaseIntegrationTest): def get_handlers_list(self): return [] def load_from_file(self, filepath): mod_name, file_ext = os.path.splitext(os.path.split(filepath)[-1]) if file_ext.lower() == '.py': py_mod = imp.load_source(mod_name, filepath) #elif file_ext.lower() == '.pyc': # py_mod = imp.load_compiled(mod_name, filepath) else: return [] class_list = [obj[1] for obj in getmembers(py_mod) if isclass(obj[1]) and obj[0] in urls[1::2]] return class_list def load_form_path(self, startPath): r = [] d = os.path.abspath(startPath) if os.path.exists(d) and os.path.isdir(d): for root, dirs, files in os.walk(d): for f in files: r.extend(self.load_from_file(root + '/' + f)) return r def test_url_generator(self): path = os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)) path = ('/'.join(path.split('/')[:-2])) + "/api/handlers/" modules = self.load_form_path(path) urls_ = [] for m in modules: url = SampleGenerator.generate_handler_url_doc(m) self.assertNotEqual(url, "URL: **Not exposed**") self.assertTrue(SampleGenerator._ishandler(m)) urls_.append(url) self.assertEqual(len(urls_), len(urls) / 2) self.assertEqual(len(modules), len(urls) / 2)

commit_message:
add a sar filter that makes it report on one line

reading sar input with multiple flags is somewhat problematic,
because it's tons of interspersed headers. So build something with
does a pivot filter to make it possible to get this all on one
line.

Change-Id: I24faf03e0324a4b28d3eb9f7e891f4d99376d7b1

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2013 Mirantis Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from climateclient import base class LeaseClientManager(base.BaseClientManager): """Manager for the lease connected requests.""" def create(self, name, start, end, reservations, events): """Creates lease from values passed.""" values = {'name': name, 'start_date': start, 'end_date': end, 'reservations': reservations, 'events': events} return self._create('/leases', values, 'lease') def get(self, lease_id): """Describes lease specifications such as name, status and locked condition. """ return self._get('/leases/%s' % lease_id, 'lease') def update(self, lease_id, name=None, prolong_for=None): """Update attributes of the lease.""" values = {} if name: values['name'] = name if prolong_for: values['prolong_for'] = prolong_for if not values: return 'No values to update passed.' return self._update('/leases/%s' % lease_id, values, response_key='lease') def delete(self, lease_id): """Deletes lease with specified ID.""" self._delete('/leases/%s' % lease_id) def list(self): """List all leases.""" return self._get('/leases', 'leases')

commit_message:
Configure plugins by name

To configure core plugin or service plugins, instead of using class names,
simpler names can also be used, ex:

service_plugins = router, firewall, lbaas

For compatibility with previous versions, the class name of a plugin can be
specified instead of its entrypoint name, ex:

service_plugins = router, neutron.services.firewall.fwaas_plugin.FirewallPlugin, lbaas

DocImpact

Implements: blueprint config-plugin-by-name
Change-Id: Ia4aaa1d305b160a4d6dab9e227c744727a4c78c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/22/64822/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: neutron.service_plugins = l3-router = neutron.services.l3_router.l3_router_plugin:L3RouterPlugin firewall = neutron.services.firewall.fwaas_plugin:FirewallPlugin lbaas = neutron.services.loadbalancer.plugin:LoadBalancerPlugin vpnaas = neutron.services.vpn.plugin:VPNDriverPlugin metering = neutron.services.metering.metering_plugin:MeteringPlugin

subject: Symlink correct element install type
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-14 22:38:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/1e8ec358b2adcbac01095b63f09606ce4466ebe5', 'message': "Symlink correct element install type

The source-repositories element will now create a symlink under the
install.d hook directory pointing to the directory (or file) that
contains the implementation for the chosen install type.

For example, the nova element would provide:

nova/install.d/74-nova
nova/install.d/nova-package-install/74-nova
nova/install.d/nova-source-install/74-nova

source-repositories will create the following symlink for the package
install type:

$TMP_HOOKS_PATH/install.d/nova-install -> nova-package-install

Or, for the source install type:

$TMP_HOOKS_PATH/install.d/nova-install -> nova-source-install

nova/install.d/74-nova then executes dib-run-parts against nova-install,
and the correct install type is executed. Note that the implementation
in install.d/74-nova is element specific. It's likely most elements will
just call dib-run-parts <element-name>-install, however they could just
as easily execute other scripts, run common install code before or after
dib-run-parts, etc.

Change-Id: I1bfaf39e5a98b2af904fbc6d674dbada30b27ed9
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-01-15 19:26:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/f3f5c63346ef1bfe5ee5d25f1f50824313c3cf94', 'message': "Symlink correct element install type

The source-repositories element will now symlink the install scripts
corresponding to the set install type for an element into the install.d
directory.

Different install types are implemented by elements by writing scripts to do
the install type under install.d/<element-name>-<install-type>-install
directories.

For example, the nova element would provide:

nova/install.d/nova-package-install/74-nova
nova/install.d/nova-source-install/74-nova

source-repositories will create the following symlink for the package
install type:

$TMP_HOOKS_PATH/install.d/74-nova -> nova-package-install/74-nova

Or, for the source install type:

$TMP_HOOKS_PATH/install.d/74-nova -> nova-source-install/74-nova

This requires a minor change in dib-run-parts to dereference symlinks when
evaluating the file's type with the find command. Using the xtype predicate
instead of type accomplishes that need.

Change-Id: I1bfaf39e5a98b2af904fbc6d674dbada30b27ed9
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-01-15 19:57:39.000000000', 'files': ['elements/source-repositories/README.md', 'elements/source-repositories/extra-data.d/98-source-repositories'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/57ba300be4ac7b932748d32466f653d1975282a2', 'message': 'Symlink correct element install type

Or, for the source install type:

commit_message:
Symlink correct element install type

The source-repositories element will now symlink the install scripts
corresponding to the set install type for an element into the install.d
directory.

Different install types are implemented by elements by writing scripts to do
the install type under install.d/<element-name>-<install-type>-install
directories.

For example, the nova element would provide:

nova/install.d/nova-package-install/74-nova
nova/install.d/nova-source-install/74-nova

source-repositories will create the following symlink for the package
install type:

$TMP_HOOKS_PATH/install.d/74-nova -> nova-package-install/74-nova

Or, for the source install type:

$TMP_HOOKS_PATH/install.d/74-nova -> nova-source-install/74-nova

Change-Id: I1bfaf39e5a98b2af904fbc6d674dbada30b27ed9

commit_message:
dib-run-parts should dereference symlinks

dib-run-parts should dereference symlinks, and if they point to an
executable file, execute that file as a script. This can be accomplished
by using the xtype predicate in the find command instead of the type
predicate.

This change is needed so that we can dynamically symlink hook scripts
into hook directories such as install.d at runtime to support different
install types.

Change-Id: I933e7f4b4dcf16956841d8c14aa63b0f9a18fc5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/23/66923/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: targets=$(find $target_dir -maxdepth 1 -xtype f -executable -printf '%f\n' | grep -E "$allowed_regex" | LANG=C sort -n)

commit_message:
Adds user_data extension to nova.api.v3.extensions

Although the user_data extension does not create a resource
or controller extension and only implements server.create and
server.create.deserialize entry points it does need to be listed as
a nova.api.v3.extension entry point as the whitelist check
operates on that entry point.

This does not add any runtime overhead and allows user_data to be
specified in the whitelist.

Also adds missing discoverable policy for the user data extension

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api

Change-Id: Ia8ac2fa150ab2fe9c1848c5a7ddc416952adf0e4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/61/42061/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
set correct include line for rhel/centos in /etc/tgt/targets.conf

Fixes: bug #1269475

If using the default lvmiscsi driver for cinder, rhel and ubuntu look in
different places for their include files. At the moment, the following line
gets added to /etc/tgt/targets.conf on rhel systems:

include /var/lib/cinder/volumes/*

This patch changes it to the correct line:

include /etc/cinder/volumes/*

Change-Id: I43b5a58b3cd77a2218cdaec3c67f3289a4e10d50
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-block-storage refs/changes/80/66880/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: include /etc/cinder/volumes/*

commit_message:
Fix bug in the api 'os-migrations'

The return is not what we are expecting:
  migration-list: 'unicode' object has no attribute 'iteritems'

The conversion of the object nova.objects.Migration into a list
is not applied automatically.

Change-Id: I3f2bf1a4c53e22c66954e1069a1bcd618a1fd52b

deleted_lines: elem.set('id') elem.set('source_node') elem.set('dest_node') elem.set('source_compute') elem.set('dest_compute') elem.set('dest_host') elem.set('status') elem.set('instance_uuid') elem.set('old_instance_type_id') elem.set('new_instance_type_id') elem.set('created_at') elem.set('updated_at') migrations = self.compute_api.get_migrations(context, req.GET)

commit_message:
Add _() to rackspace resource strings

As part of fix to bug #1249217, all the translation strings were
included in _(), but rackspace resources were ignored.
This change is to fix translation strings in rackspace resources.

Change-Id: I2a422746693136636cc137e2e9cc1bd3a7e6bb01
Closes-Bug: #1261545

commit_message:
Remove Create Backup Action For Non-Active

the "create backup" action is incorrectly shown for a non-active
database instance in the database instances table. now, only if the
instance is active, will the action/button appear.

in addition, non-active instances are now excluded from the dropdown
in the create-backup workflow.

Change-Id: Id9fdeab84ad91b96ba1a9f07ee6d1af87b6320f7
Closes-Bug: #1268260

commit_message:
New message added informing how to exit fullscreen mode.

Fixing this bug in the full screen mode involves patching it
on noVNC codebase.
This patch adds a comment for how to exit the full screen
mode using the browser's back button.

Change-Id: Ibcf510efadd6a1f29e0b2693ce9e332d54652d62
Closes-Bug:1251196

commit_message:
Using staticmethod to mock LibvirtDriver._supports_direct_io

The actual test is wrong, but does not failed because the signature
of the fake method "connection_supports_direct_io_stub" accepts an
ulimited number of args.

Change-Id: Ide3e093911723f787d9e84797be86fb7d0cd00c7

commit_message:
O'Reilly Edit: Clarification of the Scheduler

This modification removes the discussion of flavor and flavor sizing
from the Scheduler section. While flavors sizing could be appropriate
for this section, it requires defining flavors, which might cause the
discussion to tangent.

Change-Id: I3fb63ec4f079ffa590498c22697c3f3b116c8412
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/51/64751/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Fitting virtual machines into different Compute Nodes is a challenging problem, especially when the size of a new virtual machine can differ from the last. To assist with this proverbial packing problem, OpenStack Compute provides several types of scheduling drivers. For information, see Scheduling in the OpenStack Configuration Reference (http://docs.openstack.org/havana/config-reference/content/section_compute-scheduler.html). For high availability purposes, or for very large or running multiple nova-scheduler services. No special load balancing is required, as the nova-scheduler communicates entirely using the message queue.
deleted_lines: <para>Fitting various sized virtual machines (different <emphasis>flavors</emphasis>) into different sized physical nova-compute nodes is a challenging problem - researched generically in Computer Science as a packing problem.</para> <para>You can use various techniques to handle this problem though solving this problem is out of the scope of this book. To support your scheduling choices, OpenStack Compute provides several types of scheduling drivers. For information, see <link xlink:title="OpenStack Configuration Reference" xlink:href="http://docs.openstack.org/havana/config-reference/content/section_compute-scheduler.html" >Scheduling</link> in the <citetitle>OpenStack Configuration Reference</citetitle> (http://docs.openstack.org/havana/config-reference/content/section_compute-scheduler.html).</para> <para>For availability purposes, or for very large or running multiple nova-scheduler services. No special load balancing is required, as the nova-scheduler communicates entirely using the message queue.</para>

subject: Whitelist external netifaces requirement
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-01-14 12:05:44.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/efa70b41febbd2e54f0406f6434682da66598890', 'message': "Whitelist external netifaces requirement

* tox.ini(testenv.install_command): Use the --allow-external and
--allow-insecure options so that pip 1.5 and later will assent to
retrieve the netifaces  package even though it's not hosted on PyPI.
The --allow-insecure option is aliased to a clearer
--allow-unverified wording in 1.5, but the old form is being used to
avoid breaking users of 1.4.x and will be valid at least through

Partial-Bug: #1266513
"}]
commit_message:
Whitelist external netifaces requirement

* tox.ini(testenv.install_command): Use the --allow-external and
--allow-insecure options so that pip 1.5 and later will assent to
retrieve the netifaces  package even though it's not hosted on PyPI.
The --allow-insecure option is aliased to a clearer
--allow-unverified wording in 1.5, but the old form is being used to
avoid breaking users of 1.4.x and will be valid at least through
1.6.x according to comments in the pip source.

Change-Id: Ia8d5ce8152237a67da4828f3c70cf9f367d44d41
Partial-Bug: #1266513
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/48/66548/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_command = pip install --allow-external netifaces --allow-insecure netifaces-U {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
Remove unused arg `instances`

In function VolumeTableMixIn._set_id_if_nameless(), we
define arg `instances`, but we never use it.

Closes-Bug: #1269200

Change-Id: Iac828511bfe8cd417a9c965d063c388fde73052e

OpenStack "msgstr "この本をここまで読んで来たので、あなたはコミュニティの正式な個人メンバーになって、Join The OpenStack Foundation (https://www.openstack.org/join/) に加入することを考えていることでしょう。 OpenStack Foundation は、共有リソースを提供し OpenStack の目的の達成を支援する独立組織で、OpenStack ソフトウェア、およびユーザ、開発者、エコシステム全体といった OpenStack を取り巻くコニュニティを守り、活力を与え、普及の促進を行います。我々全員がこのコミュニティをできる限りよいものにしていく責任を共有します。メンバーになることはコミュニティに参加する最初のステップです。ソフトウェア同様、 OpenStack Foundation の個人会員は無料で誰でもなることができます。""blueprint directly. 開発者のインターンの視点で書かれた記事です。""href=\"http://status.openstack.org/release/\">Releases "msgstr "次のリリースに向けたロードマップと開発状況は Releases (http://status.openstack.org/release/) で見ることができます。""such as OpenStack The OpenStack ""href=\"https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OperationsTools\">recommended ""href=\"http://planet.openstack.org\">Planet OpenStack "msgstr "この本以外にも、OpenStack に関する情報源はたくさんあります。 OpenStack ウェブサイト (http://www.openstack.org) は最初に見るといいでしょう。ここには、OpenStack ドキュメント (http://docs.openstack.org) と OpenStack API ドキュメント (http://api.openstack.org) があり、OpenStack に関する技術情報が提供されています。 OpenStack wiki には、OpenStack の各プロジェクトの範囲にとどらまらない汎用的な情報が多数あり、例えば お薦めツールのリスト (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OperationsTools ) といった情報も載っています。最後に、Planet OpenStack (http://planet.openstack.org) には多くのブログが集められています。""can join. Go to the Foundation"msgstr "OpenStack Foundationは、オースチンへの航空券、(暴風後の停電によるドキドキの夜を含む)宿、そして美味しい食事で、この本の作成をサポートしました。約10,000USドルで、Rackspaceのオースチンオフィスの同じ部屋の中で、私たちは1週間で集中的に共同作業をすることができました。著者たちはすべてOpenStack
